subdoc-abstract.paragraph: A protrusion on the side of the saw tooth rubs against the newly cut kerf surface as the tooth cuts. Pressure, friction and friction-generated heat are produced through this rubbing action. The confluence of this pressure, friction, and heat, performs a polishing action against the newly cut kerf surface.

cross-reference-to-related-applications.heading: CROSS REFERENCE TO RELATED APPLICATIONS
cross-reference-to-related-applications.paragraph: [0001] This invention gives saw teeth the means for transmitting pressure, friction, and heat, to kerf surfaces. It relates to saw teeth. My co-pending application, Ser. No. 09/634,301, Cnfrm No. 5053, Filing Date Aug. 8, 2000, also provides for the transmission of pressure, friction, and heat, to kerf surfaces, but, in contrast it relates to saw blades.

section.heading: STATEMENT REGARDING FEDERALLY SPONSORED RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
section.paragraph: [0002] Not applicable

section.heading: REFERENCE TO A MICROFICHE APPENDIX
section.paragraph: [0003] Not applicable

section.heading: BACKGROUND OF THE INVENTION
section.paragraph: [0004] Saw teeth, the cutting instruments at the leading edges of saw blades, serve only to cut into the material addressed. The teeth, in motion with the blade, through a series of controlled superimposed scratches and scrapes, generate a cutting action. The newly cut kerf surfaces are not subjected to any finishing treatment by the saw teeth. The saw teeth create kerfs no smoother than their scratch scrape action allows.
[0005] Until my invention I have not heard of, or seen, or found a record of saw teeth with design elements giving them the means to polish as well as cut.

section.heading: BRIEF SUMMARY OF THE INVENTION
section.paragraph: [0006] In accordance with the present invention, the configuration of the saw tooth would include a protrusion on the side of the tooth nearest to the kerf. The prior art cutting edge of the tooth performs a conventional cutting action. The protrusion at the side of the tooth simultaneously rubs against the newly cut kerf surface. This rubbing action generates pressure, friction, and friction-generated heat, against the newly cut kerf surfaces. The confluence of pressure, friction, and heat, has a polishing effect that produces flatter smoother and denser kerf surfaces than could be produced by the teeth's scratch scrape action alone.

section.heading: BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SEVERAL VIEWS OF THE DRAWINGS
section.paragraph: [0007] FIG. 1 is a partial view of the side of a prior art circular saw blade. A protrusion is shown on the side of each second tooth, according to this invention.
[0008] FIG. 2 is a partial view of the side of a prior art band or straight saw blade. A protrusion is shown on the side of each second tooth, according to this invention.
[0009] FIG. 3 is a view in detail of the portion indicated by the section lines 3-3 in FIG. 2. of two saw teeth.
[0010] FIG. 4 is a view in detail of the portion of the saw tooth indicated by the designation 4 in FIG. 1.
[0011] FIG. 5 is a view in detail of the portion of the saw tooth indicated by the section lines 5-5 in FIG. 2.
[0012] FIG. 6 is a view in detail of a saw tooth advancing into material it is cutting, according to this invention.

section.heading: DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF THE INVENTION
section.paragraph: [0013] The protrusions 10 of FIGS. 1 and 2 illustrate protrusions 10 near the cutting edges of prior art saw teeth 12 on a prior art circular saw blade 14 and a prior art band or straight saw blades 16.

[0014] FIG. 3 illustrates protrusions 10 on the sides of two teeth 12 with the surfaces of engagement of the protrusions 18 positioned slightly further laterally from the center plane of the saw blade 20 than the extreme lateral projection of the cutting edge of the teeth 22. Each tooth has one protrusion 10 and that on the side nearest to the kerf produced by that tooth. The protrusion 10 is an inherent part of the tooth 12 and is of the same material as the tooth.
[0015] FIGS. 4 and 5 illustrate a saw tooth 12 with the protrusion's 10 surface of engagement 18 flat and parallel to the thrust of the cut.

[0016] FIG. 6 is an illustration of a saw tooth 12 advancing into material being cut 24. The surface of engagement 18 of the protrusion 10 rubs against the coarse kerf surface 26 producing a smoother kerf surface 28. The protrusion 10 is an inherent part of the tooth and is of the same material as the tooth.

section.heading: OPERATION
section.paragraph: [0017] With the foreword motion of the blade generating pressure against the material addressed 24 the saw teeth 12 perform a scratch scrape cutting action. The protrusions 10 project slightly further laterally from the center plane of the saw blade 20 than the extreme lateral projection of the cutting edge of the saw teeth 22. Simultaneous to the cutting action said protrusions rub against the newly cut Keri surfaces 26. This rubbing generates pressure, friction, and friction-generated heat. The confluence of these elements perform a polishing action against the newly cut Keri surfaces 26.

[0018] Accordingly, the reader will see that the protrusions of this invention are a practical addition to the design of saw teeth. These protrusions enable saw teeth to produce a smoother cut than would be possible without them.

[0019] Although the description above contains specificity's, these should not be construed as limiting the scope of the invention but as merely providing illustrations of a presently preferred embodiment of this invention. For example:

[0020] The design of the protrusions and their surfaces of engagement may include elements chosen from a plurality of design characteristics relating to composition, configuration, texture, and location.

[0021] Thus the scope of this invention should be determined by the appended claims and their legal equivalents, rather than by the examples given.
1
REFERENCE NUMBERS
10 protrusion at the side of the saw teeth
12 prior art saw teeth
14 saw blade, circular
16 saw blade, band or straight
18 protrusions' surface of engagement
20 center plane of saw blade
22 most lateral projection of the tooth's cuffing edge
24 material being cut
26 coarse kerf
28 smooth kerf

subdoc-claims.heading: What I claim as my invention is:

claim.claim-text: 1. A saw tooth, the improvement wherein said tooth having a lateral protrusion on the side of the tooth nearest the kerf, wherein the protrusion projects slightly further laterally from the center plane of the saw blade than the most lateral projection of the cutting edge of the saw tooth, wherein as the tooth performs its cutting action the lateral protrusion rubs against the newly cut kerf surface, whereby, a polishing action is performed on said surface.
2. The protrusion of claim 1 with the design of the protrusion and its surface of engagement chosen from a plurality of design characteristics relating to composition.
3. The protrusion of claim 1 with the design of the protrusion and its surface of engagement chosen from a plurality of design characteristics relating to configuration.
4. The protrusion of claim 1 with the design of the protrusion and its surface of engagement chosen from a plurality of design characteristics relating to texture.
5. The protrusion of claim 1 with the design of the protrusion and its surface of engagement chosen from a plurality of design characteristics relating to location.
